sectiondatas.title: Fee-for-Service Delivery System:  340B-purchased drugs billed directly to the Medicaid program
sectiondatas.description: Fee-for-Service Delivery System:  340B-purchased drugs billed directly to the Medicaid program

table_one.ingredient_cost: For eligible 340B entities listed on the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Health Resources & Service Administration (HRSA) 340B Drug Pricing Program Database, payment shall not exceed the entity's actual acquisition cost for the drug, as charged by the manufacturer at a price consistent with the Veterans Health Care Act of 1992, plus a professional dispensing fee of $10.64.
table_one.clarifying_detail: When an eligible 340B entity, other than a disproportionate share hospital, a children’s hospital excluded from the Medicare prospective payment system, a free-standing cancer hospital exempt from the Medicare prospective payment system, sole community hospital, rural referral center, or critical access hospital, submits a bill to the Medicaid Agency for a drug purchased by or on behalf of a Medicaid recipient, the amount billed shall not exceed the entity's actual acquisition cost for the drug, as charged by the manufacturer at a price consistent with the Veterans Health Care Act of 1992, plus the dispensing fee established by the Medicaid Agency. A disproportionate share hospital, children’s hospital excluded from the Medicare prospective payment system, free-standing cancer hospital exempt from the Medicare prospective payment system, sole community hospital, rural referral center, or critical access hospital may bill Medicaid the total charges for the drug. As manufacturer price changes occur, the entities must ensure that their billings are updated accordingly.
table_one.source: Alabama Medicaid Agency | Administrative Code, 560-X-1-.30 and 560-X-16-.06  | SPA Al-17-0001
table_one.question_title: How much does state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?

table_one.ingredient_cost:
Payment for covered outpatient drugs (both brand and generic) dispensed by … 340B eligible entities (including 340B contract pharmacies) not listed on the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Health Resources & Service Administration (HRSA) 340B Drug Pricing Program Database … shall not exceed the lowest of:

  • The Alabama Average Acquisition Cost (AAC) of the drug, or when no AAC is available, the Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC)+ 0%, plus a professional dispensing fee of $10.64
  • The Federal Upper Limit (FUL), plus a professional dispensing fee of $10.64
  • The provider’s Usual and Customary (U&C) charge to the general public regardless of program fees.

sectiondatas.title: Fee-for-Service Delivery System: 340B-purchased drugs billed directly to the Medicaid program
sectiondatas.description: testing

table_one.ingredient_cost:
The lesser of:
  1. the submitted actual acquisition covered outpatient drug cost;
  2. the federal upper limit established by CMS
  3. the submitted actual the estimated acquisition cost; or
  4. the estimated acquisition cost; or
  5. the state maximum allowable cost
table_one.dispensing_fee:
Dispensing fees vary based on the location of the covered entity’s dispensing pharmacy:

  • for a pharmacy located on the road system, the dispensing fee is $13.36, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug;
  • for a pharmacy not located on the road system, the dispensing fee is $21.28, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug;
  • the dispensing fee for an out-of-state pharmacy is $10.76, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug;
  • the dispensing fee for a mediset pharmacy is $16.58, to be paid not more than once every 14 days per pharmacy percovered outpatient drug.

Medicaid will also pay the provider for reasonable and necessary postage or freight shipping, not to exceed $16, incurred in the delivery of the prescription from the dispensing pharmacy to the recipient if pharmacy services are not available in the recipient's community.
table_one.clarifying_detail:
Actual acquisition covered outpatient drug cost is the unit cost that the facility pays for a drug, after subtracting all discounts. A facility may establish written protocols for establishing or calculating the facility's actual acquisition drug cost based on a monthly, quarterly, or other average of the facility's actual acquisition drug cost. A written protocol may not include an inflation, mark-up, spread, or margin to be added to the facility's actual purchase price after subtracting all discounts.

“Mediset pharmacy” means a pharmacy located in Alaska dispensing 75% or more of the total annual Medicaid prescriptions for covered outpatient drugs in prescriberordered medisets or unit doses to a recipient living in a congregate living home, a recipient of home and communitybased waiver services, a recipient eligible for Medicaid under a category set out in 7 AAC 100.002(b) or (d) who is blind or disabled, a recipient who is an adult experiencing a serious mental illness, or a recipient who is a child experiencing a severe emotional disturbance.
table_one.source: Department of Health and Social Services, Division Of Health Care Services Pharmacy & Ancillary Services Unit, March 31, 2017 Notice.  | Alaska Admin Code tit. 7, § 145.400(m) | Alaska Provider Billing Manual, Pharmacy

table_one.dispensing_fee:
Dispensing fees vary based on the location of the covered entity’s dispensing pharmacy:

  • For a pharmacy located on the road system, the dispensing fee is $13.36, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug.
  • For a pharmacy not located on the road system, the dispensing fee is $21.28, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug.
  • The dispensing fee for an out-of-state pharmacy is $10.76, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug.
  • The dispensing fee for a mediset pharmacy is $16.58, to be paid not more than once every 14 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug.

Medicaid will also pay the provider for reasonable and necessary postage or freight shipping, not to exceed $16, incurred in the delivery of the prescription from the dispensing pharmacy to the recipient if pharmacy services are not available in the recipient’s community.

table_two.clarifying_detail:
An FQHC or FQHC Look-Alike shall:
Notify the AHCCCS provider registration unit of its status as a 340B covered entity no later than:
  • 30 days after February 1, 2012
  • 30 days after registration with the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) for participation in the 340B program, or
  • the time of application to become an AHCCCS provider.

    • The FQHC or Look-Alike shall also provide the 340B pricing file to the AHCCCS Administration upon request. The 340B pricing file shall be provided in the file format as defined by AHCCCS.

    The FQHC or Look-Alike shall also identify 340B drug claims submitted to the AHCCCS FFS PBM or the Managed Care Contractors' PBMs for reimbursement. The 340B drug claim identification and claims processing for a drug claim submission shall be consistent with claim instructions issued and required by AHCCCS to identify such claims.

sectiondatas.title: Fee-for-Service Delivery System: 340B-purchased drugs billed directly to the Medicaid program
sectiondatas.description: testing

table_one.ingredient_cost:
The 340B covered entity pharmacies that carve Medicaid into the 340B Drug Pricing Program will be reimbursed at the 340B Actual Invoice Price plus the established professional dispensing fee minus the beneficiary's copayment.

Reimbursement shall be no more than the 340B ceiling price.

The ceiling price will either be provided or can be calculated by Average Manufacturer Price (AMP) minus Unit Rebate Amount (URA)].

Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) that purchase drugs through the 340B program and carve in Medicaid will be reimbursed by the encounter rate except in the case of implantable contraceptive capsules, intrauterine devices and contraceptive injections in which case reimbursement will be no more than the 340B ceiling price.
table_one.dispensing_fee:
Dispensing fee equals the average professional dispensing fee in the aggregate:

Brand and Non-preferred Brand = $9.00

Brand Preferred and Generic Medication drug = $10.50
table_one.source: Code Ark. R. 016.06.22-217.000; Arkansas SPA 16-003 | Medicaid State Plan Amendments - AR-16-003 | Code Ark. R. 016.06.22- 251.000 | Code Ark. R. 016.06.22- 251.000

table_one.ingredient_cost:
The lesser of methodology is as follows:

For brand drugs:
  • The usual and customary charge to the public or submitted ingredient cost;or
  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC), as defined in B, plus the established professional dispensing fee;or
  • The ACA Federal Upper Limit (FUL) plus the established professional dispensing fee ;or
  • The calculated State Actual Acquisition Cost (SAAC), as defined in C, plus the established professional dispensing fee.
For generic drugs:
  • The usual and customary charge to the public or submitted ingredient cost; or
  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC), as defined in B, plus the established professional dispensing fee; or
  • The ACA Federal Upper Limit (FUL) plus the established professional dispensing fee; or
  • The calculated State Actual Acquisition Cost (SAAC), as defined in C, plus the established professional dispensing fee
Backup Ingredient Cost Benchmark

If NADAC is not available, the allowed ingredient cost, unless otherwise defined, shall be thelesser of Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) + 0%, State Actual Acquisition Cost (SAAC) or ACA Federal Upper Limit
table_one.dispensing_fee:
Dispensing fee equals the average professional dispensing fee in the aggregate:

Brand and Non-preferred Brand = $9.00

Brand Preferred and Generic Medication drug = $10.50

MCOs can have their own network of Medicaid enrolled pharmacy and prescribing providers.

table_one.dispensing_fee:
Varies based on the previous year’s annual claim volume (both Medicaid and nonMedicaid) as follows:
  • Less than 90,000 claims per year: $13.20
  • 90,000 or more claims per year: $10.05
table_one.clarifying_detail:
Pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 14132.01, qualifying clinics are eligible for clinic dispensing fees not to exceed $12 per prescription, unless the drug is a take-home drug that is dispensed for use by the patient within a specific timeframe of five or less days from the date medically indicated, in which case the clinic dispensing fee is not to exceed $17 per prescription.

For physician administered drugs (PADs), the maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for immunizations shall be $9.00. The maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for other injections shall be $4.46.
table_one.source: Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 14105.45 | Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 14105.46 | State Plan Amendment (SPA) 17-002, approved August 25, 2017 | Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 14132.01 | California Code of Regulations (CCR) 51503(e) | Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code §4183

table_one.ingredient_cost:
Payment for legend and non-legend covered outpatient drugs not dispensed by a retail community pharmacy (i.e. institutional or long-term care facility pharmacies) shall be the lower of the drug’s ingredient cost plus a professional dispensing fee, or the pharmacy’s usual and customary charge to the public.

The “drug’s ingredient cost” means the lowest of:
  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) (which will be replaced with the Wholesaler Acquisition Cost (WAC) when no NADAC is available),
  • Federal upper limit (FUL),
  • Maximum allowable ingredient cost (MAIC)

PADs are the lower of the usual and customary charge or the Medicare Part B reimbursement rate plus the professional services for immunizations/injections
table_one.dispensing_fee:
The dispensing fee varies based on the previous year’s annual claim volume (both Medicaid and non-Medicaid) as follows:

  • Less than 90,000 claims per year: $13.20.
  • 90,000 or more claims per year: $10.05.
table_one.clarifying_detail: The maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for immunizations shall be $9.00. The maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for other injections shall be $4.46.
table_one.source:
SPA 17-002 | Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code §§ 14105.45 | Cal. Welf. & Inst.
Code § 14105.46 | Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR ) § 51503(e)

table_two.clarifying_detail:
Unless a covered entity, its contracted pharmacies, and the state Medicaid agency have established an arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts, the covered entity and its contracted pharmacies from using drugs purchased under the 340B program to be dispensed to Medicaid members. In addition, the covered entity must report any arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts to HRSA. DHCS incorporated this requirement into the California Medicaid State Plan for the Medi-Cal program (FFS and managed care) via State Plan Amendment 17-002.

The terms of the required arrangement must be formalized in the MCO’s policies and procedures and approved by DHCS, prior to the MCO allowing or initiating a 340B contract pharmacy arrangement within its provider network.
table_two.source: Draft All Plan Letter | Pharmacy Fee-For-Service  Reimbursement Changes

table_one.dispensing_fee:
For all pharmacies except government and rural pharmacies, dispensing fees are tiered as follows:

  • • Fewer than 60,000 total prescriptions filled per year = $13.40
  • Between 60,000 and 90,000 total prescriptions filled per year = $11.49
  • Between 90,000 and 110,000 total prescriptions filled per year = $10.25
  • More than 110,000 total prescriptions filled per year = $9.31
  • For government pharmacies: $0.00
  • For rural pharmacies: $14.14
table_one.clarifying_detail: Health First Colorado requires covered entities to determine whether they will dispense only 340B drugs to Health First Colorado members (carve-in) or whether they will dispense no 340B drugs to Health First Colorado members (carve-out). Covered entities cannot bill both 340B purchased drugs and non-340B drugs to Health First Colorado.

table_one.ingredient_cost:
The lower of:
  • The usual and customary charge to the public; or
  • The allowed ingredient cost plus a professional dispensing fee.
table_one.clarifying_detail:
The allowed ingredient cost is the lesser of Colorado Actual Acquisition Cost (AAC) or submitted ingredient cost. If AAC is not available the allowed ingredient cost is the lesser of Wholesale Acquisition Cost or submitted ingredient cost.

The Department shall update AAC on a regular basis based on changes in pharmacies' acquisition costs and national pricing benchmarks such as WAC. The AAC price list is available through the Department' s website (colorado.gov/hcpf)

table_one.ingredient_cost:
Brand name single source and multisource drugs will reimburse at the Brand NADAC price while generic drugs will reimburse at the Generic NADAC price. Claims for drugs without a NADAC price will reimburse at the lesser of the Federal Upper Limit (FUL) or the Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) with the following exceptions, which will always reimburse at WAC:

  • Preferred brand name medications (as identified on the Preferred Drug List (PDL), and
  • medications submitted with a Dispense as Written Code of “1” (Substitution Not Allowed-Brand Medically Necessary), for all HUSKY A, HUSKY C, HUSKY D, TB AND FAMPL recipients.
table_one.clarifying_detail: Dispensing fees are only paid on reimbursable pharmacy claims submitted with a National Drug Code (NDC) of a legend drug.
table_one.source: Provider bulletin 2017- 10

table_two.clarifying_detail:
The HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File.

In addition, the State has advised that for fee-for-service 340B pharmacy claims:

  • Providers dispensing 340B outpatient drugs must be registered as a 340B provider
  • A value of “08” must be submitted in the Basis of Cost Determination field (NCPDP field #423-DN). (A Basis of Cost Determination value of “05” will no longer be acceptable.)
  • The amount submitted in the Ingredient Cost Submitted field (NCPDP field #409-D9) must be less than the reference price as provided by Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.
  • A value of “20” must be submitted in the Submission Clarification Code field (NCPDP field #420-DK).
table_two.source: Email correspondence with Florida’s Senior Pharmacist, Agency for Health Care Administration, Bureau of Medicaid Policy

table_two.clarifying_detail:
Provider-level indicators.

Providers using 340B drugs for Medicaid patients are required to report this information on the MEF.

Claim-level indicators.

Covered entities must bill the Georgia Medicaid Division with a submission clarification code of 20 on Fee-For-Service (FFS) and Care Management Organizations (CMO) outpatient pharmacy claims. Claims must include the HCPCS code, UD modifier, and National Drug Code (NDC) as well. For products ineligible for 340B pricing, the UD modifier is not included.

For single-source drugs, shall not exceed the lower of:
  • The provider’s invoice price
  • The provider’s usual and customary charge to the general public; or
  • The estimated acquisition cost (EAC).
For multiple source drugs, shall not exceed the lower of:
  • The provider’s invoice price;
  • The provider’s usual and customary charge to the general public;
  • The EAC;
  • The Federal Upper Limit (FUL) price; or
  • The State Maximum Allowable Cost (SAMC).

table_one.dispensing_fee:
Based upon the annual volume of the enrolled pharmacy, the professional dispensing fee is:
  • Fewer than 40,000 claims a year = $15.11
  • Between 40,000 and 69,999 claims per year = $12.35
  • 70,000 or more claims per year = $11.51

table_two.clarifying_detail:
Providers using 340B drugs for Medicaid patients are required to report this information on the MEF.

Non-pharmacy providers must identify 340B-purchased drugs by reporting modifier “UD” in conjunction with the appropriate drug CPT or HCPCS code. Pharmacy providers submitting claims through the point-of-sale system for drugs purchased through the 340B program must identify the drug as a 340B-purchased drug by populating the Submission Clarification Code (420-DK) field with a value of “20.” Providers are required to add the dispensing fee to the provider charge.
table_two.source:
Handbook for Practitioners Rendering Medical Services, Ch. A-200, Policies and Procedures, § A-202.1.6.

Payment is based on the lowest of:
  • National Average Drug Acquisition Cost plus dispensing fee
  • State Maximum Allowable Cost plus dispensing fee
  • Federal Upper Limit plus dispensing fee
  • Wholesale Acquisition Cost, minus a percentage as determined by the office through analysis of the dispensing cost survey or other methodology approved by CMS, plus the dispensing fee
  • Usual & Customary

sectiondatas.description: DRAFT

table_one.ingredient_cost:
The lowest of:

  • National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC)
  • Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC)
  • Federal Upper Limit (FUL)
  • Kentucky-established Maximum Allowable Cost (MAC)
  • Usual & Customary
  • 340B ceiling price
table_one.clarifying_detail: For a drug purchased through the 340B Program and administered by a physician or the physician’s authorized agent in an office or outpatient clinic setting, and submitted for reimbursement as a medical benefit, the lowest of logic shall include the 340B ceiling price. The covered entity shall bill no more than the actual 340B acquisition cost. A professional dispensing fee shall not be paid for PAD.
table_one.source: Kentucky Administrative Regulations. 907 KAR 23:020. Reimbursement for outpatient drugs
table_one.question_title: How much does state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?

questions.question: How much does state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?

table_one.clarifying_detail: A drug dispensed by a 340B contract pharmacy shall not be eligible as a 340B transaction and shall be reimbursed in accordance with the lowest of logic as required by Section 2 of this administrative regulation plus the professional dispensing fee.
table_one.source: Kentucky Administrative Regulations. 907 KAR 23:020. Reimbursement for outpatient drugs

The state has advised that providers using 340B drugs for Medicaid patients are required to report this information on the MEF. No specific state provisions located.

The provider shall support all Department based efforts and initiatives for 340B claim identification at a claim level of detail, including the utilization of the NCPDP fields designed for this purpose. questions.question: What mechanism does State Medicaid program use to identify 340B-purchased drugs billed by covered entities to an MCO so that they can exclude them from their rebate requests to manufacturers?

table_two.clarifying_detail:
The state has advised that contract pharmacies may not submit claims to Medicaid MCO for 340B-acquired drugs, unless there is an agreement in place with the State, the covered entity, and the contract pharmacy. This covered entity must report this agreement to HRSA.

In addition, the Kentucky Medicaid Managed Care Master Agreement states that the provider shall support all Department based efforts and initiatives for 340B claim identification at a claim level of detail, including the utilization of the NCPDP fields designed for this purpose. Provider must require pharmacy providers or processing vendors to identify 340B purchased drugs on claims.
table_two.source:
Email correspondence with the Pharmacy Director, Cabinet for Health and Family Services, Department of Medicaid Services on July 9, 2019.

Contract for Medicaid Managed Care Services Between The Commonwealth of Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services, Division of Medicaid Services and Anthem Kentucky Managed Care Plan, Inc., August 2018

  • Usual and customary charges or
  • Gross amount due

table_one.ingredient_cost: The amount of payment is the lower of the ingredient costs of the drugs plus the professional dispensing fee, or the usual and customary price charged to the public. The usual and customary price means the lowest price charged by the provider to a patient who pays for the prescription by cash, check or charge account and includes prices the pharmacy charges to a patient enrolled in a prescription savings club or prescription discount club administered by the pharmacy or pharmacy chain. NADAC or the State Maximum Allowable Cost (SMAC) is used to determine the ingredient cost of a drug.
table_one.clarifying_detail: The amount of payment basis must be reduced to reflect all discount amounts applied to the charge by any third-party provider/insurer agreement or contract for submitted charges to medical assistance programs. The net submitted charge may not be greater than the patient liability for the service.
table_one.source:
Minn. Stat. Ann. § 256B.0625(13)(e) (please note that this statute is not effective until Medicaid State Plan Amendment 19-06, currently open for public comment, is approved by CMS).

sectiondatas.description: Fee-for-Service Delivery System: 340B-purchased drugs billed directly to the Medicaid program

table_one.ingredient_cost:
The lower of:

  • Usual and customary charge to the general public

*Allowed ingredient cost is the lowest of:

  • Average Acquisition Cost (AAC)
  • Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC)
  • Federal Upper Limit (FUL)
  • Submitted ingredient cost (for 340B drugs, submitted ingredient cost means the actual 340B purchase price)
table_one.dispensing_fee:
The dispensing fee assigned shall range between:
  • The minimum of $2.32 and the maximum of $15.14 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume between 0 and 39,999
  • The minimum of $2.32 and the maximum of $13.12 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume between 40,000 and 69,999; or
  • The minimum is $2.32 and the maximum is $11.10 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume greater than 70,000.
table_one.source: Montana Prescription Drug Program Manual - Reimbursement

table_one.clarifying_detail:
AAC means the actual prices paid by a pharmacy to acquire drug products marketed or sold by manufacturers. The maximum allowable ingredient drug cost, calculated based on an AAC, is defined as the lowest of:

  • National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) or in the absence of a NADAC price, Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) less two percent
  • The Federal Upper Limit (FUL) price for covered outpatient drugs
  • The State Upper Limit (SUL) price for covered outpatient drugs (calculated as 100% of drug acquisition costs for covered outpatient drugs as determined by State-sponsored pharmacy surveys)
  • The 340B Drug Discount Program ceiling price or in the absence of a 340B ceiling price, WAC less twenty-five percent
  • A pharmacy’s usual and customary charge.
table_one.source: NJMMIS Newsletter, Volume 27, No. 4 (State Coverage and Reimbursement for 340B Drugs)

  • National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) or in the absence of a NADAC price, Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) less two percent
  • The Federal Upper Limit (FUL) price for covered outpatient drugs
  • The State Upper Limit (SUL) price for covered outpatient drugs (calculated as 100% of drug acquisition costs for covered outpatient drugs as determined by State-sponsored pharmacy surveys)
  • WAC less twenty-five percent
  • A pharmacy’s usual and customary charge

table_one.ingredient_cost:
For brand name drugs, the lower of:

  • National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) or, in the event of no NADAC pricing available, Wholesale Acquisition Cost less 3.3%
  • Billing pharmacy’s usual and customary price charged to the general public

For generic drugs, the lower of:

  • NADAC or, in the event of no NADAC pricing available, WAC less 17.5%
  • Federal Upper Limit (FUL)
  • State Maximum Allowable Cost
  • Billing pharmacy’s usual and customary price charged to the general public

For generic drugs, the lower of:

  • FUL
  • State Maximum Allowable Cost
  • Billing pharmacy’s usual and customary price charged to the general public

table_one.dispensing_fee:
Professional dispensing fee is tiered:
  • Less than 49,999 prescriptions per year = $13.64
  • Between 50,000 and 74,999 prescriptions per year = $10.80
  • Between 50,000 and 74,999 prescriptions per year = $9.51
  • 100,000 or more prescriptions per year = $8.30

table_one.dispensing_fee:
Professional dispensing fee is tiered:
  • Less than 49,999 prescriptions per year = $13.64
  • Between 50,000 and 74,999 prescriptions per year = $10.80
  • Between 50,000 and 74,999 prescriptions per year = $9.51
  • 100,000 or more prescriptions per year = $8.30

For pharmacy claims (NCPDP format), the covered entity must identify claims for drugs purchased through the 340B program by submitting Submission Clarification Code (NCPDP Field 420-DK) “20” and Basis of Cost Determination (NCPDP Field 423-DN) “08.”

For hospitals and noninstitutional providers, Ohio Medicaid uses claim indicator (modifier) SE and a validation check to HRSA files to ensure/verify the billing provider is a covered entity, as the source that the drug should be excluded from rebate for outpatient and professional FFS claims.

table_two.clarifying_detail:
The HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File. Covered entities are required to report any changes to the Oklahoma Health Care Authority (OHCA) within 30 days.

To prevent a duplicate discount, quarterly adjustments will be made to all pharmacy or medical claims for drugs submitted by the covered entity. OHCA will adjust each claim by subtracting the 340B Ceiling Price from the amount reimbursed and multiplying the difference by the quantity submitted. All drugs shall be adjusted by the 340B Ceiling Price whether purchased through the 340B program or otherwise when billed using the registered SoonerCare NPI number on the HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File.
table_two.source: OHCA Policies and Rules, 317:30- 5-87. 340B Drug Discount Program

table_two.clarifying_detail:
HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File:

“Covered entities that will carve-in are required to inform HRSA (by providing their Medicaid provider number/NPI) at the time they enroll in the 340B Program that they will purchase and dispense 340B drugs for their Medicaid patients. If covered entities decide to bill to Medicaid for 340B purchased drugs with a Medicaid provider number/NPI, then ALL [fee-for-service and Coordinated Care Organization] drugs billed to that number must be purchased under 340B and that Medicaid provider number/NPI must be listed on the HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File.”

  • Long-term care (LTC) pharmacy: NADAC minus 2.4%
  • Specialty pharmacy: NADAC minus 1.7%

  • Retail pharmacy = (WAC minus 2%)
  • LTC pharmacy = (WAC minus 3.4%)
  • Specialty pharmacy = (WAC minus 8%)

table_two.clarifying_detail:
Covered entities participating in the 340B program are required to identify in the proper field of the Texas Medicaid Pharmacy Provider Enrollment application that they are eligible to purchase products under the 340B program.

Covered entities participating in the 340B program must use modifier “U8” when submitting claims for 340B clinician-administered drugs

In addition, pharmacies of eligible entities participating in the 340B Program must identify all outpatient pharmacy claims filled with 340B drugs by submitting a value of "2Ø" ("34ØB / Disproportionate Share Pricing/Public Health Service") in the "Submission Clarification Code" field (42Ø-DK).”

table_two.clarifying_detail:
All claims submitted to Utah Medicaid from a 340B covered entity for medications that were purchased through the 340B program must be submitted:

  1. For point of sale claims, this is indicated by using Submission Clarification Code = 20 and Basis of Cost = 08.
  2. For provider administered claims, this is indicated by adding the “UD” modifier to claim.
  3. For provider administered Medicare crossover claims, this is indicated by adding the “JG” or “TB” modifiers.

table_two.clarifying_detail:
There are two processes in place. Initially, all NPI’s for covered entities ’s enrolled in the Medicaid 340B program are excluded from rebate processing. Subsequently, a manual reconciliation process occurs whereby the covered entity is provided a paid claims file for the previous month. The covered entity is asked to validate the drugs are that are 340B, and provide their 340B acquisition cost (AC). A financial settlement occurs to assure that Medicaid receives the AC. Anything identified by the covered entity as non-340B eligible is then included for rebate processing.

Alternatively, a pharmacy may submit the 340B AC on the claim using the proper NCPDP submission codes (submission clarification code “20” and Basis of cost “8”) for a 340B claim. All claims with 340B identifiers are excluded from rebate processing
table_two.source: Provider Communication March 2019, and supplemented by email correspondence with Director of Pharmacy Services, Department of Vermont Health Access on August 7, 2019

table_two.clarifying_detail: As noted above, outpatient pharmacy point-of-sale drugs are carved out of the MCO contract. For physicianadministered drugs, each pharmacy and medical encounter must include a 340B indicator, supplied by the provider at the time of billing, verifying whether or not a 340B drug was dispensed/adm inistered to the Medicaid member. The MCO shall report this information using a standardized template supplied by the Department. The MCO must validate their 340B drug cost claims data by confirming that drug costs for 340B prescribed drugs do not exceed non340B costs for the same drug and provide quarterly attestation that the verification has been completed.
